posts.cooked:
Over the course of the last year, our team has been discussing about switching to another language in the future. Some of us believe that python could gain popularity, and some of us believe that many teams will stay with Java because switching is a learning curve and would take time to transfer. We just want to know what other teams are thinking about doing and the value in switching or sticking with a certain language. I didn’t want to have too many options to pick from so I apologize to the teams who use c++

We currently use Java and are staying with Java We currently use python and are staying with python We currently use Java and are switching to python We currently use python and are switching to Java 0 voters

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked:
Our team has historically used Java. I’m not the biggest fan of it, but it’s easy to learn/teach and has the most FRC library support of the three languages.

I’d personally like to try out Kotlin over the summer just to see how well it is supported, since it has a much more modern and less verbose syntax.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
programminggonewrong:

I apologize to the teams who use c++

Bruh…
Yeah I’m sorry, I am actually a big c++ fan and I felt bad for not putting it as an option

I think Kotlin is also gaining more traction. I’d love to switch, and if it was just me I’d do it, but it isn’t just me.

(edited) To expand further on this, I find Java to be the most terrible language I touched (at least out of the serious ones), and I’ve touched many programming languages. It’s too verbose and its semantics are oddly different from other languages in a way I can’t really describe. From the little I have tried and from what I hear, Kotlin is significantly better and interoperates pretty well with Java (while Java is bad in my opinion, the JVM is really rather good), and good enough for FRC that I’d trust it. Unfortunately, I am not the only one who needs to write code, and training and support are much more available for Java. I’ve considered trying Python for FRC , but it suffers from the same problem.

I also see @ArchdukeTim is replying and I know 78 switched to Kotlin this year.
Yeah I’ve seen a few teams use kotlin and it seems very interesting. I tried to learn it one time a bit ago and remember liking it a lot.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
our team has been discussing about switching to another language in the future

Any particular reason why? I don’t recommend switching just for the sake of switching. In 2014, 1418 switched from Labview to Python. We were planning on switching to Java, but then ‘The RobotPy Guy’ became our mentor so we went with that instead. Eventually those that knew python better graduated and they’ve since switched back to java.

This year, 78 gave Kotlin a try. I use it for work, and find it easier to write code than in Java. It also plays extremely nicely with the current build tools provided by WPILib, so it isn’t a huge burden to maintain interoperability.

I predict that Kotlin will gain more popularity than python over time, simply because of the similarity to Java. So if you’re trying to stay ahead/with the curve, I don’t think python is the way to go. Though, now that python is officially supported, it may gain traction even faster than in years past.

Most teams choose languages for one of 2 reasons:

They choose a language taught by their school

They choose a language taught by their mentor(s)

These factors don’t change very often, nor predictably, so I don’t expect many teams to respond that they are switching languages.

If you really do want to switch, I would recommend Kotlin because I think FRC code benefits a lot from its features.

posts.name: Sam Perlmutter
posts.cooked:
ArchdukeTim:

I think FRC code benefits a lot from its features.

Which kotlin features are you thinking of that would be of most benefit?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
Operator overloading I think has been one of the most used for us. All of the WPILib geometry classes support the operators, such as

where both are Rotation2d instances.

In java, you’d have to do

Another useful feature is extension properties. C++ allows you to have user-defined literals . Java has no such luck, but with kotlin, an extension property on Number lets you create literals for all of the WPILib unit classes:

Then later in code you can do

Likewise, converting back to a double can be accomplished with a similar property:

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked:
I’m a huge fan of kotlin and I highly recommend https://www.learncs.online/ for learning Java and kotlin. There’s a fantastic “toggle” feature where you can go back and forth between the languages.

That said, I’m having a hard time justifying the switch for our team. I don’t really worry about interop, it’s fantastic. The tooling is also excellent. IntelliJ’s Java to kotlin converter is slick. You can even paste Java code into kotlin sources and it will just convert it. The biggest hurdle is introducing an entirely new programming language to students. AP CSA is only Java and it feels like it will be forever. They’ll have to read Java anyway to understand all the code samples out there. There’s just a lot of inertia.

link_counts.title: Learn CS Online: An Introduction to Computer Science

posts.name: Ryan Smith
posts.cooked:
This is our team’s 3rd year using Kotlin, and we love it. We use operator overloading and a lot of the shorthand (like when statements ). We originally switched because me and our other code captain really disliked Java. We discussed C++ and Python (two languages both of us already had experience with), but ultimately decided against them (because of a combination of difficulty in onboarding and lack of ecosystem support).

Overall, we’ve been pretty happy with the decision. It has been fairly easy to onboard kids from our school’s Java curriculum (specifically AP Computer Science A), and we plan to stick with Kotlin moving forward.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked:
Nice!

I’m acutally pretty wary of operator overloading and infix functions for that matter. Narrowly used, they can be very useful, but they’re also “cool” which has the potential to lead to bad bugs and unreadable code.

Yes that’s what I think too. The issue is, there are new programmers this year who are trying to convince our lead mentor to switch the coding language to python because it is easier and newer. Obviously since I think that staying with java is the better option, my mentor asked me to conduct surveys and find evidence that we should stay with java. I also do agree that if we were to switch, I would vote for either kotlin or C++

posts.name: Ryan Smith
posts.cooked: Yeah, operator overloading definitely has its drawbacks. Kotlin allows you to attach documentation to operators, so it is slightly clearer than if it was just the operator, but we still use it sparingly in our code

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
We went to Python in 2024 when it was officially supported. Prior to that it was Java. Vendor support is sometimes lacking, but overall I’m happy with the move.

One is that our VEX kids can get into Python prior to FRC . So that kinda keeps things continuous for them. Heck, you can use blocks to program and have it write the Python for you. Easy way into the language.

There’s also notebooks. Handy little teaching environments, no install, just open a webpage.  Now we can learn about variables and functions and ifs and loops and stuff like that. Easy to get them rolling.  I try and do some of these with students in the pre-season to get them used to programming and Python.

It’s also what all of our scouting analysis tools are written in. So, knowing one helps with the other a bit. Or at least gives you some confidence than you can jump from robot coding to wrestling pandas.

And it’s not Java. It was never a tidy language but I feel like after the Oracle acquisition the language evolved rapidly and not in a controlled manner. The syntax is pretty much universally disliked. I don’t want to throw students into that mess.

We tend to do some math with our robot code. The more the better, and while we can abstract that away with a library usually it’s sometimes nice to actually have the students implements it themselves. And Java is a terrible language for math. Python is kind of the gold standard there.

I’ve also been really happy with the tooling. Robotpy ships out of the box with some unit tests, you can get a basic sim/physics engine going pretty easy, and with the magicbot framework things just come together really clean. Toss in something like the Drop Bear’s project setup that uses ‘uv’ to manage python libraries and a student only needs to install uv, git clone our rep, and ‘uv sync’ to install python and all libraries. Once that’s done ‘uv run robotpy sim’ and they’re able to run the robot and test their code changes. You don’t even need to touch the FIRST installers.

If you’re still with me, I feel like it’s a much better tool for the task at hand and a much better tool for students to learn with. The only thing Java has going for it is momentum.
